#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=CHAPTER II
#Text=Like every other woman , she had had an affair of the heart .
#Text=Her father , who was a mason , was killed by falling from a scaffolding .
#Text=Then her mother died and her sisters went their different ways ; a farmer took her in , and while she was quite small , let her keep cows in the fields .
#Text=She was clad in miserable rags , beaten for the slightest offence and finally dismissed for a theft of thirty sous which she did not commit .
#Text=She took service on another farm where she tended the poultry ; and as she was well thought of by her master , her fellow-workers soon grew jealous .
#Text=One evening in August ( she was then eighteen years old ) , they persuaded her to accompany them to the fair at Colleville .
#Text=She was immediately dazzled by the noise , the lights in the trees , the brightness of the dresses , the laces and gold crosses , and the crowd of people all hopping at the same time .

#Text=She was standing modestly at a distance , when presently a young man of well-to-do appearance , who had been leaning on the pole of a wagon and smoking his pipe , approached her , and asked her for a dance .
#Text=He treated her to cider and cake , bought her a silk shawl , and then , thinking she had guessed his purpose , offered to see her home .
#Text=When they came to the end of a field he threw her down brutally .
#Text=But she grew frightened and screamed , and he walked off .
#Text=One evening , on the road leading to Beaumont , she came upon a wagon loaded with hay , and when she overtook it , she recognised Theodore .
#Text=He greeted her calmly , and asked her to forget what had happened between them , as it “ was all the fault of the drink . ”
#Text=She did not know what to reply and wished to run away .
#Text=Presently he began to speak of the harvest and of the notables of the village ; his father had left Colleville and bought the farm of Les Ecots , so that now they would be neighbours .
#Text=“ Ah ! ” she exclaimed .
#Text=He then added that his parents were looking around for a wife for him , but that he , himself , was not so anxious and preferred to wait for a girl who suited him .
#Text=She hung her head .
#Text=He then asked her whether she had ever thought of marrying .
#Text=She replied , smilingly , that it was wrong of him to make fun of her .
#Text=“ Oh ! no , I am in earnest , ” he said , and put his left arm around her waist while they sauntered along .
#Text=The air was soft , the stars were bright , and the huge load of hay oscillated in front of them , drawn by four horses whose ponderous hoofs raised clouds of dust .
#Text=Without a word from their driver they turned to the right .
#Text=He kissed her again and she went home .
#Text=The following week , Theodore obtained meetings .
#Text=They met in yards , behind walls or under isolated trees .
#Text=She was not ignorant , as girls of well-to-do families are -- for the animals had instructed her ; -- but her reason and her instinct of honour kept her from falling .
#Text=Her resistance exasperated Theodore ’s love and so in order to satisfy it ( or perchance ingenuously ) , he offered to marry her .
#Text=She would not believe him at first , so he made solemn promises .

#Text=But , in a short time he mentioned a difficulty ; the previous year , his parents had purchased a substitute for him ; but any day he might be drafted and the prospect of serving in the army alarmed him greatly .
#Text=To Felicite his cowardice appeared a proof of his love for her , and her devotion to him grew stronger .
#Text=When she met him , he would torture her with his fears and his entreaties .
#Text=At last , he announced that he was going to the prefect himself for information , and would let her know everything on the following Sunday , between eleven o’clock and midnight .
#Text=When the time grew near , she ran to meet her lover .
#Text=But instead of Theodore , one of his friends was at the meeting-place .
#Text=He informed her that she would never see her sweetheart again ; for , in order to escape the conscription , he had married a rich old woman , Madame Lehoussais , of Toucques .
#Text=The poor girl ’s sorrow was frightful .
#Text=She threw herself on the ground , she cried and called on the Lord , and wandered around desolately until sunrise .

#Text=Then she went back to the farm , declared her intention of leaving , and at the end of the month , after she had received her wages , she packed all her belongings in a handkerchief and started for Pont-l’Eveque .
#Text=In front of the inn , she met a woman wearing widow ’s weeds , and upon questioning her , learned that she was looking for a cook .
#Text=The girl did not know very much , but appeared so willing and so modest in her requirements , that Madame Aubain finally said :
#Text=“ Very well , I will give you a trial . ”
#Text=And half an hour later Felicite was installed in her house .
#Text=At first she lived in a constant anxiety that was caused by “ the style of the household ” and the memory of “ Monsieur , ” that hovered over everything .

#Text=Paul and Virginia , the one aged seven , and the other barely four , seemed made of some precious material ; she carried them pig-a-back , and was greatly mortified when Madame Aubain forbade her to kiss them every other minute .
